name: Julián Castro
tweet: Too often, LGBTQ individuals are still discriminated against in housing, employment, education, and other services. The #EqualityAct will make sure all people are protected from discrimination. @senatemajldr should put this bill on the Senate floor for a vote immediately.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: Brown v. Board declared racially segregated schools unconstitutional 65 years ago, but our schools are more segregated today than anytime since the 1960s. We must do more to combat inequalities in education—my People First Ed plan addresses this head on. http://bit.ly/PeopleFirstEd

name: Julián Castro
tweet: As I state in my essay, "Discrimination doesn’t happen only when we mean for it to happen." It pervades our policies, institutions, and decision making everyday. The question is whether we have the collective will to recognize and combat it.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: It's time to amend the Fair Housing Act to end practices with a discriminatory impact, including those that victimize people with criminal records. It's bigger than a legal principal, it's how we talk about discrimination against marginalized communities in the 21st century.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: That's also why we released guidance that provided federal protections against housing discrimination for folks with criminal histories—a critical step if we are going to focus on reentry after incarceration. Landlords shouldn't be able to ban returning citizens from housing.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: That's why we launched Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing (AFFH), a HUD rule to help communities desegregate & reduce criminal justice inequalities. AFFH is good housing policy, good civil rights policy, and good criminal justice policy—but it's under attack by this admin.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: Black & brown communities experience disproportionate police presence, and the result is a higher-than-average rates of arrest. Those interactions—even without convictions—lead to housing instability and homelessness at a much higher rate than the general public. It's connected.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: Housing policy is criminal justice reform. I saw this firsthand as Sec. of @HUDgov under President Obama. Where someone lives dictates the likelihood that they will interact with the criminal justice system. Racially-segregated communities are much more likely to be over-policed.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: I wrote an essay for the @BrennanCenter in which I argue that we must reimagine our conception of justice to be holistic, to see it as an interconnected web that impacts communities in ways far beyond what we typically associate with criminal justice. https://www.brennancenter.org/publication/ending-mass-incarceration-ideas-todays-leaders …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: On January 20, 2021 we will have an opportunity to get this right. As President, I will lead us to an immigration system that actually benefits America.  Before we get there, though, I need your help. Please support our campaign. http://bit.ly/julianforthefuture …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: They returned a few weeks later and, protected by a court order and the U.S. Army, made it to Montgomery. Because of their bravery, and that of countless others, the Voting Rights Act of 1965 was signed that same spring. #SelmaJubilee

tweet: Nearly 54 years ago, 600 civil rights warriors attempted their first march from Selma to Montgomery for voting rights. name: Julián Castro
tweet: During my time in public service, I had the chance to visit over 40 states, which helped me understand the issues most important to the people I served. I want to do that again. Over the course of my campaign, I will visit every state in our nation to hear directly from you.

tweet: As someone from a state that’s largely been ignored by presidential campaigns for most of the past four decades, I know how much it means for the people in every state to have a chance to be heard by the men and women seeking to become their President.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: I just left Chicago, 45 miles from Aurora, IL. I am praying for the victims and families. But we know, we do, that this doesn’t have to happen over and over. Don’t let the gun lobby write firearm policies that generate profit and accept mass murder. We must unite against it.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: We no longer have 3 co-equal branches of government. The President, in taking money designated by Congress for other needs to build his senseless wall,  has voided the voice of the people. The real national emergency is the constitutional crisis the President just instigated.

tweet: 7 million Americans have lost health insurance under this President. Bad deal. We need Medicare for All now—everybody counts in this country, and everyone should get good health care when they need it. #SOTU

tweet: You want to outcompete China? We should start by building alliances around the world, not tearing them down. #SOTU

name: Julián Castro
tweet: The only “crisis” at the border is the one this President created: thousands of children taken away from their parents and a cruel, incompetent administration unwilling to reunite them.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: The President offers a false choice: security or compassion for immigrants. We can have both. Invest in personnel, technology and secure ports of entry AND forge a path to earned citizenship for the millions of law-abiding undocumented immigrants already here.

tweet: If the President wants unity, he can start be uniting all the children and parents his administration tore apart from each other at the border. #SOTU

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "The lesson I learned from my mother so many years ago in this community is that when we want to see change in our community, we don’t wait for it. We work for it."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "My story wouldn’t be possible without the strong women who came before me and passed me the baton. Because of their hard work, I have the opportunity to stand here today."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Hoy en día, esta comunidad representa el futuro de Estados Unidos: diverso, de rápido crecimiento, optimista, un lugar donde personas de diferentes orígenes se han unido para crear algo verdaderamente especial."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: I am proud to call myself a son of San Antonio. Home is always San Antonio.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Today, this community represents America’s future—diverse, fast-growing, optimistic, a place where people of different backgrounds have come together to create something truly special."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "This is a community built by Native Americans. Families who worked to serve our future."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Esta es una comunidad construida por inmigrantes, familias de México. Pero también de Alemania y otros países. Y también de Nativos Americanos"

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "This is a community built by immigrants—families from Mexico.  But also from Germany and other countries."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Esta es una comunidad como muchas otras comunidades en nuestro país.Una comunidad de buenas personas. Gente humilde Las personas que se presentan temprano al trabajo y se quedan tarde (muchas veces en más de un trabajo) para que puedan mantener a su familia."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "This is a community of good people.  Humble people.  People who show up for work early and stay late—oftentimes at more than one job—so they can provide for their family."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Miren a su alrededor, no hay ni un candidato delantero a la presidencia que haya nacido aquí, pero siempre he creído que con grandes sueños y trabajo duro todo es posible."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Look around, there are no frontrunners born here but I've always believed that with big dreams and hard work anything is possible."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Esta mañana, tomé el autobús número 68 con mi hermano por la calle Guadalupe, como lo hacíamos tantas veces como niños. Y esta vez traje a mi hija Carina."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "This morning, I rode the number 68 bus with my brother down Guadalupe Street as we did so many times as kids. Only this time I brought my daughter Carina with me."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Es donde ella creció, donde trabajó durante años como sirvienta, cocinera y niñera mientras criaba a mi madre como madre soltera."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "It’s where she grew up, where she worked for years as a maid, a cook and a babysitter while raising my mother as a single parent."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "Este lugar — el lado oeste de San Antonio — es un lugar especial para mi. Este es el lugar al que llegó mi abuela, Victoria, en 1922, cuando emigró de México cuando era una huérfana de siete años."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: "This place—the west side of San Antonio— is a special place for me. This is the place my grandmother, Victoria, came to in 1922 when she immigrated from Mexico as a seven-year-old orphan."

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 24. We have a lot of work to do. But as I travel across the country and talk with young people, I’m impressed by a generation of young leaders who are up for a challenge. And when I think about where we will be 50 years from now, my money’s on progress. END

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 23. Fifty years after Dr. King’s assassination we still mourn his loss, but his legacy includes the Fair Housing Act, passed a week after his death. So on today's anniversary, we have a chance not just to celebrate, but to recommit to its promise. #FairHousingis50

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 22. Economists Chetty and Hendren came out with a new study this year. It underlines what so many people knew intuitively: race > class when determining futures. Even with economic status, racism still lingers. The two are inextricably linked in housing.  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/03/19/upshot/race-class-white-and-black-men.html …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 21. Black communities are dangerously overpoliced and police violence continues to ravage black communities and claim the lives of unarmed young African Americans with little accountability or justice. Black lives matter and where black families live matters.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 20. So where do we go from here? For one, we need to vote. Every single election. We all must educate ourselves about the issues (from trustworthy sources). These issues don't just affect black and brown folks—segregation holds back our entire society from greater prosperity.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 19. Closing that loophole in the Fair Housing Act in 2015 was something I'm very proud of my HUD team for accomplishing. In addition, we expanded fair housing rights for domestic violence survivors, transgender individuals, and returning citizens. https://medium.com/@SecretaryCastro/criminal-justice-reform-includes-housing-fd29940fc598 …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 18. President Obama believed deeply in the promise of the Fair Housing Act and his administration crafted a policy in 2015, the Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing rule, requiring that American communities actively work to integrate. https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2015/07/11/weekly-address-making-our-communities-stronger-through-fair-housing …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 17. The abrupt change has been described as an effort to “roll back the Obama administration’s attempts to reverse decades of racial, ethnic and income segregation." So what were we doing at HUD in the Obama administration that was so scary to right-wingers?

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 16. Congress's spending bill actually prohibits HUD from helping municipalities desegregate. This goes beyond neglect, and is more likely the active undermining by Republicans of a reasonable policy meant to level the playing field for millions of disenfranchised Americans.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 15. In my last months at HUD, we opened up an investigation of Facebook for allowing advertisers to exclude certain racial and ethnic groups when placing real estate ads on the platform. HUD recently abandoned that suit. Fortunately, NGOs are on the case.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 14. Example B, from just last week: Under Ben Carson, HUD Scales Back Fair Housing Enforcement https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/28/us/ben-carson-hud-fair-housing-discrimination.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fus&action=click&contentCollection=us&region=rank&module=package&version=highlights&contentPlacement=6&pgtype=sectionfront …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 13. Example A, from January 2018: Trump Administration Postpones an Obama Fair-Housing Rule https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/upshot/trump-delays-hud-fair-housing-obama-rule.html …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 12. This administration actively rejects its responsibility to enforce fair housing rules. In 2015, the current Secretary famously dismissed our efforts to enforce fair housing as "social engineering." https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jul/23/ben-carson-obamas-housing-rules-try-to-accomplish-/ …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 11. That's why I called HUD the Department of Opportunity. HUD can change lives, it can help improve our entire society.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 10. At the same time, investing in neglected neighborhoods through effective place based work can also make a positive difference in people’s lives. We need to embrace both these approaches, to give folks meaningful options.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 9. Providing a housing voucher for a greater-opportunity neighborhood to a low-income family with young children gives those kids a fighting chance in life. They will have better jobs. They will earn more money. They will enjoy better health and accrue social benefits.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 8. Segregated communities where people of color live are significantly more likely to expose children to environmental hazards. Lead poisoning limits a child's potential and Flint still doesn’t have clean water. https://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/flint-water-crisis/cdc-confirms-lead-levels-shot-flint-kids-after-water-switch-n598496 …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 7. Every year a child lives in a neighborhood with greater opportunity -- better schools, racial diversity, a strong middle class -- the more that child will earn over her lifetime. https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/04/upshot/an-atlas-of-upward-mobility-shows-paths-out-of-poverty.html …

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 6. How do we know that fair housing still matters? Strong data. The economists Raj Chetty and Nathaniel Hendren have produced important analyses of how critical a child's zip code is to her future.  http://www.equality-of-opportunity.org/neighborhoods/

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 5. Sadly, the goals of the Fair Housing Act have yet to be realized. Racial segregation endures, and the folks of color living in these communities have worse outcomes than their white peers because of fewer education, economic, and professional opportunities.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 4. It was the last major piece of Civil Rights legislation. The Fair Housing Act required local communities to desegregate, to undo government policies that encouraged segregation -- post-WWII policies like the GI Bill that gave preference to white homebuyers in the new suburbs.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 3. When MLK was assassinated in 1968, as the nation wrestled with grief, and riots rocked cities from Chicago to Washington, DC, President Johnson pushed Congress to pass the law that Dr. King had lobbied for several years to pass without action.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 2. As HUD Secretary under President Obama it was my job to enforce the Act. So on the 50th anniversary of the Fair Housing Act, I have some thoughts about the past, present, and future of fair housing.

name: Julián Castro
tweet: 1. 50 yrs ago, a week after MLK's assassination, President Johnson signed into law the Fair Housing Act, which promised to address racial housing discrimination & proactively dismantle the pervasive racial segregation America's federal housing policy had created. #FairHousingIs50
